title: 111_hr2424
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009". It includes findings related to the Federal Reserve. The Congress found that in August 2007, liquidity dried up in credit and securities markets, initially affecting financial firms with interests in mortgage-backed securities. This lack of credit access spread globally, leading to the Federal Reserve setting a target range of 0 to 0.25 percent for the Federal funds rate in December 2008. The Federal Reserve established a target range of 0 to 0.25 percent for the Federal funds rate in response to the financial crisis. The Board of Governors exercised its authority to address unusual circumstances multiple times since the crisis began, with the last instance before that being in 1934. During the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve provided assistance to nonmember institutions for the first time since 1959 and purchased debt obligations from government-sponsored enterprises for the first time since 1981. Additionally, joint programs were established with the Department of the Treasury to aid financial markets, including guaranteeing assets of Citigroup and Bank of America, the Term Asset-Backed Securities Lending Facility, and the Public-Private Partnership Investment Program. Chairman Ben Bernanke affirmed his commitment to transparency regarding the Federal Reserve's lending programs and balance sheet during a testimony to the Committee on Financial Services of the House of Representatives on February 10, 2009. SEC. 3. REVIEWS OF SPECIAL FEDERAL RESERVE CREDIT FACILITIES. Section 714 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Comptroller General to conduct reviews of credit facilities established by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System or any Federal reserve bank. This includes onsite examinations when deemed necessary. The Federal Reserve Bank can act as the lender of last resort and provide temporary assistance to private institutions through various credit facilities. These facilities include the Money Market Investor Funding Facility, Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility, Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility, and Term Auction Facility. The Federal Reserve Bank provides temporary assistance to private institutions through various credit facilities, including the Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility, Term Auction Facility, Primary Dealer Credit Facility, Commercial Paper Funding Facility, Term Securities Lending Facility, Maiden Lane LLC, Maiden Lane II LLC, Maiden Lane III LLC, Revolving Credit Facility, Reciprocal currency arrangements with foreign central banks, and Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program. The Federal Reserve Bank provides temporary assistance to private institutions through various credit facilities, including the Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program and the purchase of debt obligations from a Government Sponsored Enterprise. Any special purpose vehicle conducting activities or lending through such credit facilities will cease after a 5-year period. A report on each review conducted must be submitted to Congress by the Comptroller General within 90 days of completion. The report under subparagraph (A) shall include a detailed description of the findings and conclusion of the Comptroller General with respect to the review, along with recommendations for legislative or administrative action. SEC. 4. ACCESS TO RECORDS. Access to Records under Section 714(d)(1) and (2) of title 31, United States Code is amended to grant the Comptroller General access to agency records and credit facility records. The Comptroller General can request access to officers, employees, contractors, and representatives at any reasonable time and make copies of records as deemed appropriate. Unauthorized access is prohibited, with the amendment allowing the Comptroller General to make copies of any records. Section 714(d)(2) of title 31, United States Code is amended to allow the Comptroller General to make copies of any records and access credit facility records established by an agency.
